lines.text: Father, could I... tell you in the Irish?

[distracted, fishing]
Sea, sea.

[very hesitantly]
Níor lig mé m'fhear chéile isteach i mo leaba liom aréir. Chuir mé fuinneamh air a chodladh i - Ó, i mála codlata! Mála codlata!
Céad é sin? "Bag?"
Sleeping bag, Father, with... with buttons! Más breá é, níor rith sé ar a shon. An peaca é?

[exasperated]
Woman, Ireland may be a poor country, God help us. But here, a married man sleeps in a bed, not a bag!
Could you use a little water in your whiskey?
When I drink whiskey, I drink whiskey; and when I drink water, I drink water.
Ah, yes... I knew your people, Sean. Your grandfather; he died in Australia, in a penal colony. And your father, he was a good man too.
Sir!... Sir!... Here's a good stick, to beat the lovely lady.
May their days be long and full of happiness; may their children be many and full of health; and may they live in peace... and freedom.
There'll be no locks or bolts between us, Mary Kate... except those in your own mercenary little heart!
It's a bold one you are! Who gave you leave to be kissin' me?
So you can talk!
Yes I can, I will and I do! And it's more than talk you'll be gettin' if you step a step closer to me!
Don't worry - you've got a wallop!
You'll get over it, I'm thinkin'.
Well, some things a man doesn't get over so easy.
Like what, supposin'?
Like the sight of a girl coming through the fields with the sun on her hair... kneeling in church with a face like a saint...
Saint indeed!
...and now coming to a man's house to clean it for him.
But... that was just my way of bein' a good Christian act.
I know it was, Mary Kate Danaher. And it was nice of you.
Not at all.
He'll regret it till his dying day, if ever he lives that long.
I'll count three, and if you're not out of the house by then, I'll loose the dogs on you.
If you say "three," mister, you'll never hear the man count "ten."
[first lines]

Well, then. Now. I'll begin at the beginnin'. A fine soft day in the spring, it was, when the train pulled into Castletown, three hours late as usual, and himself got off. He didn't have the look of an American tourist at all about him. Not a camera on him; what was worse, not even a fishin' rod.
[last lines]
No patty-fingers, if you please. The proprieties at all times. Hold on to your hats.
Is this a courting or a donnybrook? Have the good manners not to hit the man until he's your husband and entitled to hit you back.
Father! Father Lonergan!

[not wanting to disturb the fish]
Ssh, ssh, ssh, ssh, ssh.
It's a big fight in the town!
Listen, there's a big fight in this fish right here, too.
I'd have put a stop to it, but seeing it's...
You do that, lad. It's your duty.
But seeing it was Danaher and Sean Thornton...
[Father Lonergan turns at stares at Father Paul in amazement]
WHO?
Danaher and Sean Thornton!
WELL WHY THE DEVIL DIDN'T YOU TELL ME? Oh, you young...
[Throws down his fishing rod and the two run back into town. They abruptly stop behind a gate]
Father, shouldn't we put a stop to it now?

[relishing the fight from a distance]
Ah, we should, lad, yes, we should, it's our duty!
Mind you, I'm fresh as a daisy!
You look more like a Black-Eyed Susan to me.

He's a nice, quiet, peace-loving man, come home to Ireland to forget his troubles. Sure, yes, yes, he's a millionare, you know, like all the Yanks. But he's eccentric - ooh, he is eccentric! Wait 'til I show ya... his bag to sleep in - a sleeping bag, he calls it! Here, let me show you how it operates.
I don't get this. Why do we have to get you along? Back in the States, I'd drive up, honk the horn, the gal'd come runnin'...
Come a-runnin'? I'm no woman to be honked at and come a-runnin'!
America - ha! Prohibition! You see that over there? That's the ancestral home of ancient Flynns. It was taken from us by... by... by the Druids!
[stops the cart]
Quietest couple I ever heard. We'll get nowhere at this rate. Off with ya!
[Sean tries to help Mary Kate down]
She's a fine healthy girl - no patty-fingers if ya please!
I have a fearful temper. You might as well know about it now instead of findin' out about it later. We Danahers are a fightin' people.
I can think of a lot of things I'd rather do to one of the Danahers - Miss Danaher.
Shhh, Mr. Thornton! What will Mr. Flynn be thinkin'?

[on seeing the broken bed]
Impetuous! Homeric!
Well it's a nice, soft night, so I think I'll go and join me comrades and talk a little treason. G'night, Sean.
G'night, Michaleen.
What manner of man is it that I have married?
A better one, I think, than you know, Mary Kate.
If anybody had told me six months ago that today I'd be in a graveyard in Innisfree with a girl like you that I'm just about to kiss, I'd have told 'em...
Oh, but the kisses are a long way off yet!
Huh?
Well, we just started a-courtin', and next month, we, we start the walkin' out, and the month after that there'll be the threshin' parties, and the month after that...
Nope.
Well, maybe we won't have to wait that month...
Yup.
...or for the threshin' parties...
Nope.
...or for the walkin' out together...
No.
...and so much the worse for you, Sean Thornton, for I feel the same way about it myself!
[They kiss. Thunder rolls]

[drunk]
Woman-of-the-house! I have brought the brother home to supper!
[Throws hat]
He is kindly welcome.

[also drunk]
God bless all in this house...
Wipe your feet!
Thank you mum!
Ah, what a day for Innisfree! On a day like this, I can say only one thing - Gentlemen, the drinks are on the house!
[pub patrons suddenly stop their conversations and stare at him in stunned silence]
Well, they are!
Now I want youse all to cheer like Protestants!
Can't you get it through your head that I don't care about your money?
But he does, and that's the whole point!
I have... I have come.
Oh, I can see that. But from whose pub was it?
Pub? Pub? You've the face of an angel with the tongue of an adder. I have a good mind to go about me own business and tell Thon Shorton he's better off without ya!
Wait a minute, what was that?
Well ye be listenin' then and not interrupting the shockelhorn - the matchmaker... I have come at the request of Thon Shorton...
Sean Thornton.
Shut up... bachelor and party of the first part, to ask if you, uh - strictly informally, mind you - eh, Mary Kate Danaher, spinster, and party of the second part.
Well. Go on. You were sayin'?
Actually... me mouth is like a dry crust and the sun is that hot on me pate.
Will you be steppin' into the parlor? The house may belong to my brother, but what's in the parlor belongs to me.
I will then... and I hope there's a bottle there, whoever it belongs to...
If you've come for supper, you're late.
A gracious invitation, but, thank you, no.
I'll let you buy me a drink, at your wake! Ha!

[looking thirsty]
I don't suppose there's a drop of anything wet in the house?
Help yourself to the buttermilk.
Buttermilk!
[shudders and in sotto voice]
The *Borgias* would do better.

[seeing mob approaching]
I, I think your in-laws are commin' to pay you visit, Squire darlin'.

[after falling in a stream]
Have ya had enough?
No!
Well then, give a man a hand.
...and her with her freckles and her temper. Oh, that red head of hers is no lie.
Is that a bed, or a parade ground? A man would have to be a sprinter to catch his wife in a bed like that.

[Looking at the reverend]
Three Our Fathers and three Hail Marys.
So the I.R.A.'s in this too, huh?
If it were, Red Will Danaher, not a scorched stone 'o your fine house'd be standin'.
A beautiful sentiment!
Two women in the house - and one of them a redhead!

[Chasing Sean and Mary Kate on horse, the horse instinctively stops in front of Cohan's Bar. Talking to horse]
I... I Think you have more sense then I have me-self.
None 'o that now, none 'o that. It's a bold sinful man y'are Sean Thornton. And who taught you to be playin' patty-fingers in the Holy Water?
Just bein' polite, is all.
And Mary Kate Danaher dippin' her fingers in as neat as you please.
So you told him all that, did you?
That I did.
Down at the pub I suppose, and in front of all those big ears with pints in their fists and pipes in their mouths.
I could tell you blood curdling stories about him but, but me throat, me throat's gone dry.
A pound on Thornton against the Squire!
Go away, ye traiter, ya!
Si' down, si' down. That's what chairs are for.

[During the big fight scene and after getting doused with water for the nth time]
Thanks.
Father? Little Flynn?
Well, I can't say it's true, and I won't say it's not, but there's been talk.
